question: On page 13, extract the introductory paragraph immediately following the 'Carbon Table 2' title. Ensure the extraction is free of any page headers, navigation tabs, or document titles located at the top of the page.

model_answer.answer: Microsoft’s Scope 3 emissions continue to account for more than 97% of our total emissions. Tackling Scope 3 means decarbonizing industrial processes such as steel, concrete, and other building material production for use in our campus and datacenter construction, as well as jet fuel for business travel and logistics, with the vast majority of these emissions coming from two categories upstream, Purchased Goods and Services (Category 1) and Capital Goods (Category 2), and one downstream, Use of Sold Products (Category 11).
model_answer.rationale: On printed page 13 (PDF page 5), under the label 'Carbon Table 2' and the section heading 'Breaking down our FY24 Scope 3 emissions by source', the introductory paragraph begins with 'Microsoft’s Scope 3 emissions continue...' and summarizes the sources of emissions.

scores.correctness_justification: Perfect match to the ground truth with no extraneous elements.
scores.judge_reasoning: Perfect match to the ground truth with no extraneous elements.

question: On page 49, extract the main body text under the 'Protecting ecosystems' heading. Do not include the '>30%' statistic or the 'Land protection' sidebar text located to the left of the main column.

model_answer.answer:
Healthy ecosystems are essential for life on Earth. They provide clean air, water, food, and countless other benefits that sustain communities, economies, and ecosystems globally. Yet these ecosystems face mounting threats from climate change and biodiversity loss, and require urgent and coordinated action.

Our approach
Microsoft recognizes the interconnectedness of ecosystem health with all aspects of sustainability. From supporting pollinator habitats at our campuses to integrating biodiversity into datacenter designs, we are embedding ecological considerations into our operations. Through partnerships with conservation organizations and the application of innovative technologies, we are helping to monitor, protect, and restore ecosystems, driving meaningful environmental impact at both local and global scales.
model_answer.rationale: Extracted the main introductory paragraph and the 'Our approach' section text from page 49, as these constitute the main body text under the 'Protecting ecosystems' heading. Excluded the 'Land protection >30%' sidebar, charts, and 'Our target'/'Our progress' sidebars as requested.

scores.correctness_justification: Model correctly extracted the first paragraph but included additional text beyond the specified boundary.
scores.judge_reasoning: Model correctly extracted the first paragraph but included additional text beyond the specified boundary.

question: Extract the full narrative text under the heading 'Replenishment activities' on page 30. Strictly exclude the text inside the blue '+50%' callout box and the chart labels.
On page 29, extract a description of the growth trend shown in the 'Total contracted volume' chart. Specifically, describe the visual difference in growth magnitude between FY22 and FY24.

model_answer.answer: The 'Total contracted volume water replenishment' chart illustrates a rapid acceleration in growth between FY22 and FY24. In FY22, the volume was 13,230,308 m³, while in FY24, it rose to 50,031,857 m³. This represents a visual difference in growth magnitude of nearly four times (approximately 3.8x) over the two-year period.
model_answer.rationale: On page 29 (PDF slice 9), 'Water Table 1' displays bar charts for 'Total contracted volume water replenishment'. The bar for FY22 is labeled '13,230,308' and the bar for FY24 is labeled '50,031,857', showing a steep increase in the trend line.

scores.correctness_justification: Model misinterprets growth magnitude, describing overall increase instead of year-specific trends.
scores.judge_reasoning: Model misinterprets growth magnitude, describing overall increase instead of year-specific trends.
